key_points: Gabby Petito's disappearance and subsequent confirmation of her death as a homicide has received extensive media coverage.
Petito's case exemplifies 'missing white woman syndrome', highlighting racial and class disparities in media attention to missing persons.
Petito already had a significant online following, contributing to the virality of her case on social media platforms.
The disproportionate media attention has implications for policy priorities and resource allocation by officials for search and investigation efforts.
Petito's case raises concerns about racial bias in media coverage and the potential for algorithmic bias on social media platforms.
Women of color, especially Black and Indigenous, are more likely to go missing and receive less media attention.
Underreporting and poor coordination contribute to the lower official rates of missing Indigenous women.
The extensive resources used in the search for Petito contrast with the lack of similar efforts for hundreds of missing Indigenous people in Wyoming.
The disproportionate media attention to missing white women reflects broader societal issues, including violence against women and systemic racism.
The article suggests that if Petito had been Black, her case might not have received the same level of public attention.
